persona.name: Erica Santos

occupation.title: Currently unemployed (primary caregiver / homemaker)
occupation.description: Erica is currently unemployed, focusing full-time on childcare for two young children (ages 4 and 1). Previously she worked intermittently in informal, low-paid jobs: sales assistant at a sari-sari store, part-time food stall helper in a wet market, and occasional house cleaning for neighbors. She knows how to handle cash, keep a simple logbook, and run small errands. Her practical experience includes basic food preparation, child feeding schedules, diapering, and managing household supplies on a tight budget. She has considered small-income activities such as selling homemade snacks (kakanin), reselling secondhand clothes online, or doing sewing repairs. She is open to part-time neighborhood work but worries about reliable child care and costs of commuting. Her main barriers to formal employment are lack of childcare, recent lack of work documentation or references, and limited formal qualifications beyond high school.

persona.education: High school graduate (public high school). Finished secondary education at 17. Some short community vocational trainings (basic sewing, food handling) but no tertiary degree.
long_term_goals: Provide a more stable, safer childhood for her children than she had.
Return to part-time work or start a small home business within 2 years to contribute to household income.
Save enough to buy a small condo unit or modest house in a safe neighborhood within 10 years.
Make sure both children complete at least secondary school and, if possible, some vocational training.
Be able to take her family on a short vacation to the beach once a year.
Build a small emergency fund to avoid borrowing from loan sharks.
Gain more confidence speaking English so she can apply for better jobs or online freelance work.
Strengthen her relationship with her spouse and establish a more equal parenting routine.
Teach her children simple values: kindness, respect, and curiosity.
Be more involved in a local community group that supports young parents.
persona.style: Warm, approachable and practical. Speaks Tagalog with a light Metro Manila accent; code-switches to basic English for short phrases ("okay na", "I'll do it later"). Uses familiar colloquialisms and polite honorifics when talking to elders ("po", "opo"). Voice is medium-pitched, often soft when talking about personal struggles, louder and animated when excited about the children. Frequently laughs with a short nasal chuckle. Uses hands to gesture when telling a story; taps her left wrist when thinking of time. Prefers comfortable, functional clothing: simple cotton tops, jeans or skirts, rubber slippers for daily errands; reserves one nicer dress and flats for family events or church. Carries a worn canvas tote bag with diapers, wet wipes, a small notebook, and a phone charger. Tends to speak in short, concrete sentences; not fond of academic language. When upset she becomes quieter, uses brief answers, and avoids confrontation by changing the subject or stepping away. In social settings she is hospitable — offers visitors tea or snacks. Values punctuality for children’s routines but is flexible for community obligations. Often hums children's songs while doing household chores. When stressed, her speech speeds up and she fidgets with a hair tie.

traits: Deeply family-oriented and protective of her children.
Practical and resourceful under pressure; finds small creative solutions for daily problems.
Emotionally warm and affectionate, quick to comfort others.
Anxious about finances and the future; tends to ruminate at night.
Persistent and resilient; recovers from setbacks slowly but steadily.
Modestly proud — cares about her reputation in the neighborhood.
Sometimes shy with authority figures but polite and respectful.
Tends to avoid conflict; prefers harmony and compromise.
Has a gentle sense of humor; enjoys light teasing and childish jokes.
Occasionally prone to guilt (about not earning enough, about parenting choices).
Values routines and small rituals (family dinner, prayer before bed).
Curious about small new things (new recipes, new social media tricks) but dislikes large, rapid changes.

big_five.openness: Medium. Willing to try new foods and small ideas (online selling, new recipes) but cautious about major life changes.
big_five.conscientiousness: Medium-High. Organized about daily chores, children's schedules and household budgeting; sometimes misses longer-term planning due to stress.
big_five.extraversion: Medium. Enjoys friendly neighborhood socializing, church groups and barangay gatherings but values private time and is not the center of attention.
big_five.agreeableness: High. Cooperative, trusting, helpful and forgiving; dislikes confrontation.
big_five.neuroticism: Medium-High. Experiences worry about money, guilt about parenting decisions, occasional crying spells and stress-related insomnia.

interests: Spending time with her children at the nearby park, watching them play.
Cooking simple Filipino dishes and experimenting with affordable versions of recipes she sees online.
Watching daytime teleseryes and family-oriented shows for relaxation.
Following a few mommy vloggers on Facebook and TikTok for parenting tips and budget recipes.
Church activities: attending Sunday Mass and participating in the parish's mothers' group occasionally.
Bargain-hunting at public markets for fresh produce and sale items.
Sewing small repairs and hemming clothes; occasionally finishing simple alterations for neighbors for a small fee.
Listening to Original Pilipino Music (OPM) ballads while cleaning or cooking.
Listening to short podcasts about parenting and household money tips when cooking.
Gardening small potted herbs on the balcony: basil, chili, and malunggay.
likes: Adobo made with extra garlic and a little sugar.
Cheap grilled corn from a street vendor as a family treat.
Rice porridge (lugaw) on rainy days and when kids are slightly sick.
Bright-colored inexpensive clothes for the children (they look cheerful).
Sari-sari store coffee in the morning to quickly wake up.
Discount days at the wet market or community sale.
Birthday celebrations with a simple cake and a few balloons.
Children's cartoons in the evening as family wind-down.
Used children's books in good condition from neighbors.
Reusable cloth diapers for playing outdoors and disposable ones for overnight.
Plastic containers that stack neatly and are easy to wash.
Chats with other moms in the barangay about local schools and teachers.
Homemade merienda (kakanin, banana cue) to sell sometimes for extra cash.
Hand-me-down toys that remind her of her own childhood.
Simple beauty routines: coconut oil for hair, running water facial wash, occasional salon visit for a trim.
Mobile phone apps that help with budgeting or calculating monthly household expenses.
Watching her children achieve small milestones (first words, first steps).
Handing small allowances to her older child and teaching simple saving (a coin jar).
dislikes: Being judged by neighbors for parenting choices or household condition.
High-pressure salespeople and loan collectors who call about unpaid short-term loans.
Crowded jeepney rides during the peak hours with two children—feels unsafe.
Expensive baby products that feel unnecessary or out of budget.
Long bureaucratic processes to access government benefits.
Loud, aggressive people; she withdraws when confronted.
Seeing wasteful spending on non-essentials in her household.
Children's illnesses that could have been prevented with better access to care.
People who act superior because they have more money or education.
Cleaning up after parties especially when guests leave a mess.
Complex online forms or processes that require many IDs and paperwork.
food_and_drinks: Favorite breakfast: pandesal with margarine and instant coffee.
Favorite snack to make and sell: sweet rice kakanin wrapped in banana leaf.
Treat for kids: chocolate-flavored powdered milk and small biscuits.
Comfort food: chicken tinola with a lot of ginger when someone is sick.
Coffee habit: one small instant coffee sachet in the morning; sometimes gets brewed coffee from a neighbor.
Vegetables she prefers: kangkong (water spinach), eggplant, okra.
Avoids: very spicy foreign dishes; she likes local flavors.
Occasional splurge: fried chicken bucket for family during payday.
media_and_technology: Uses a basic Android smartphone, single SIM, limited data plan.
Active on Facebook: posts photos of children, reads community notices, sells items via marketplace.
Occasional TikTok consumer: watches short clips for recipes, parenting hacks and cheap clothing hauls.
Prefers short videos and visual how-tos rather than long articles.
Relies on messenger groups (family, church, barangay) for neighborhood updates.
shopping_and_consumption: Prefers wet market for fresh produce and bulk rice purchases to save money.
Buys secondhand children's clothes from community bazaars or online resellers.
Checks price tags carefully and compares per-kilo price rather than impulse buying.
Uses piggy bank and sometimes pawns a small item when desperate for cash.
Likes affordable local brands over imported or boutique items.
parenting_preferences: Favors gentle discipline: time-outs for big violations, verbal reminders and distraction for toddlers.
Believes in early reading: reads short picture books to her 4-year-old each night.
Prefers nearby public daycare or playgroup with low fees when available.
Values vaccination and follows the local health center schedule.
Emphasizes family meals and simple rituals like prayer before bed.
social_preferences: Enjoys small gatherings with other mothers at the barangay hall.
Less comfortable at formal events with 'high-society' neighbors; dresses modestly and keeps a low profile.
Likes to help neighbors: cooking extra food and sharing, exchanging childcare favors.

beliefs: Family comes first; children’s needs take precedence over personal wants.
Hard work and patience will eventually pay off, even if progress is slow.
Education is the most reliable way out of poverty for the next generation.
Being a 'good mother' means sacrificing some personal comfort for children's wellbeing.
Church and prayer provide strength during difficult times.
Government programs can help but are often bureaucratic and slow.
Neighbors and barangay networks are essential safety nets in times of need.
Borrowing small sums from relatives or local lenders is normal but must be handled carefully.
Children should be vaccinated and taken regularly to health centers for check-ups.
It is shameful to let your kids go hungry; feeding them well is a moral duty.
Women can and should contribute financially when possible, even through informal work.
There is dignity in small honest work: sari-sari store selling, baking, cleaning.
Money management is about small daily choices: buy fewer snacks, save small amounts frequently.
Taking on small loans sometimes unavoidable for emergencies but dangerous if repeated.
It's important to teach children manners: 'po' and 'opo', saying sorry, respecting elders.
Education beyond high school is desirable but not always achievable; vocational skills are worthy alternatives.
Mental health is real but often stigmatized; people are expected to 'pull themselves together'.
Her spouse should participate in childcare, but cultural expectations still place most day-to-day care on the mother.
Stay-at-home parents are undervalued even though the work is hard and continuous.
Neighbors will gossip; maintaining appearances matters to avoid undue criticism.
Government cash transfers are appreciated but rarely enough; they help at critical moments.
Sending remittances or saving money for a child’s education is the best long-term investment.
Household budgeting notebooks (a simple ledger) are extremely useful for keeping track of scarce resources.
Children learn more by example than by instruction: parents must model kindness and honesty.
It's safer to avoid confrontations with aggressive people; escalate only to authorities if necessary.
Recycling and reusing items is smart and a moral responsibility when resources are limited.
Cheap, local remedies sometimes work for minor illnesses but professional health care is necessary for serious issues.
Small businesses started from home (food, sewing, resale) are practical first steps for mothers returning to work.
Having a support network (mother, sister, close friend) is crucial when a child is ill or when emotional support is needed.
One should be careful about online scams and offers that promise quick money; they often take more than they give.
skills: Childcare expertise: feeding schedules, bathing, diapering, soothing techniques, recognizing fever and common childhood illnesses.
Basic first aid for children: cleaning small cuts, using fever reducers, applying simple wound dressings.
Household budgeting: tracking daily expenses, stretching rice and ingredients, prioritizing essential purchases.
Cooking: competent in a range of Filipino dishes (adobo, sinigang, tinola, lugaw) and quick, child-friendly meals.
Basic sewing and mending: hemming pants, sewing buttons, patching small tears.
Small-scale food preparation and packaging for sale: making and wrapping kakanin, frying banana cue, simple portioning.
Sales and customer interaction: experience at sari-sari store and market stalls; friendly interpersonal skills.
Social media basics: posting photos, messaging, using Facebook Marketplace and private groups to sell items.
Time management for household routines and children's schedules.
Light cleaning and basic home maintenance: unclogging small drains, changing light bulbs, fixing loose cabinet hinges.
Good observational skills: noticing changes in children's behavior or health.
Negotiation skills at the market: bargaining per kilo, comparing offers.
Ability to keep a simple handwritten ledger and receipts.
Multitasking under stress: preparing meals while supervising a toddler.
Basic conversational English (everyday phrases) used with school staff or when reading parenting resources in English.

general: Consciously conserves electricity and water to keep bills low; turns off lights in unused rooms.
Keeps a small stack of ready-to-go snacks and water bottles for unexpected outings with the kids.
Always carries wet wipes and spare clothes for the younger child.
Smiles and greets neighbors; willing to trade favors like babysitting or buying groceries.
When upset, steps out to the balcony or alley to breathe and sometimes cries quietly.
Tends to over-apologize when hosting guests if something is not perfect.
Checks children's school or daycare caregiver at midday if someone can cover her errands.
Uploads photos of children to a private Facebook album and shares milestone updates with family.
Frequently asks other mothers for informal advice on parenting choices.
Uses a small physical notebook to jot expenses, doctor appointments, and children's milestones.

morning: Wakes between 5:00–6:00 AM to prepare simple breakfast (pandesal, eggs) and warm water for the younger child.
Prepares children's clothes and packs small snack for the older child's daycare or playgroup.
Quick prayer or quiet moment before starting the day; sometimes listens to a short radio devotional.
Sweeps the small living area, boils water for the day, and repacks the family's refillable water container.
If doing small selling work, gets small food items ready to sell at 8:00 AM at a nearby footpath.
daytime / workday: Spends mornings running errands: buying groceries, paying utility bills, or visiting the health center for vaccinations.
Attends to household chores between 9:00 AM and 1:00 PM: laundry, cleaning, sweeping, cooking lunch.
If there is a casual job opportunity (cleaning, selling), she takes it for a few hours, arranging childcare with a neighbor or spouse.
During hot afternoons she keeps the younger child indoors and encourages quiet play or naps.
Checks community Facebook groups for items to buy or sell; responds to buyer inquiries in chunks of time.
evening: Prepares and serves the family's main meal around 6:00–7:00 PM, making sure children eat first.
Baths the children, reads a short picture book to the older child and sings lullabies.
Chats with her spouse about the day, bills and possible small income activities.
Spends 30–60 minutes watching a favorite TV program or browsing social media once the children sleep.
Updates the small ledger, puts aside coins in the piggy bank and plans the next day’s errands.
weekend: Attends Sunday Mass with the family or listens to an online service if children are sick.
Visits extended family or receives visitors; participates in small parish or community events.
Often does deeper cleaning and prepares more elaborate meals if there is extra time or money.
Goes to the market early when there are better deals and fresher produce.
May run a small bake sale or accept a sewing job to supplement income on Saturdays.

physical: Generally healthy for an adult: no chronic non-communicable diseases diagnosed.
Had a normal vaginal delivery for both children; postpartum recovery was routine though one delivery had moderate anemia treated at the public clinic.
Mild iron deficiency historically after childbirth; takes iron supplements occasionally when prescribed.
Occasional urinary tract infection once a few years ago, treated with antibiotics.
All family members follow the national immunization schedule for children; Erica keeps vaccination records.
Has mild asthma symptoms when exposed to heavy smoke or pollution; uses an over-the-counter inhaler rarely (no formal inhaler prescription).
Occasional headaches, often tension-type related to poor sleep or dehydration.
No known allergies other than occasional eczema flare-ups on the toddler's skin from new detergents.
mental: Experiences situational anxiety related to finances and future prospects—sleeps restlessly when worried.
Has experienced brief postpartum blues after each birth but no diagnosed postpartum depression; she is aware of red-flag symptoms and has supportive family members.
Occasional low mood, especially on days with no money or when a child is sick; cries privately sometimes.
Finds relief through social support (mother, sister, close friend) and prayer.
Open to seeking counseling if affordable or available via local health center but has not accessed professional mental health services.
health_behaviors: Takes children to the barangay health center for check-ups and vaccines.
Uses home remedies for mild coughs (ginger tea) and goes to the public clinic if fevers persist.
Does not smoke and avoids exposure to cigarettes for the children.
Tries to prepare nutritious meals within budget: vegetables, fish, and occasional meat.
Does limited regular exercise: brisk walking with children in the evening when safe.

relationships.name: Miguel Santos
relationships.description: Married for 6 years. Works irregularly as a construction helper and sometimes as a tricycle driver. Earns variable daily wages, sometimes piecemeal. He is affectionate but sometimes comes home late after odd jobs. Shares responsibility for bigger purchases and helps with heavy lifting and discipline. Tends to be pragmatic, occasionally frustrated by financial stress. They argue sometimes about money but reconcile quickly. Both prioritize the children's needs.

relationships.name: Alejandra 'Aling' Santos (née Cruz)
relationships.description: Lives in the same barangay two alleys away. Provides crucial childcare backup when Erica needs to work or attend appointments. Traditional values, often gives practical advice and sometimes unsolicited criticism. Respected by Erica and helps with household chores and cooking when needed.

relationships.name: Rafael Santos
relationships.description: Works in a nearby factory; sends small occasional help. Reliable for emergency loans and advice. Close relationship but limited time because of his shift work.

relationships.name: Katrina Reyes
relationships.description: Huge emotional support. They often exchange babysitting favors, share recipes, and talk daily over the fence. Helps Erica with online selling tips and sometimes purchases goods to help family cash flow.

relationships.name: Barangay health worker and midwife
relationships.description: Supportive and trusted source for child health and vaccination. Helps track growth charts and offers occasional parenting sessions at the barangay hall.

relationships.name: Small circle of other mothers
relationships.description: Exchange babysitting, secondhand clothes, and informal tips. They meet informally during mornings at the community playground or barangay events.

relationships.name: Employer references
relationships.description: Informal references: sari-sari store owner, a neighbor who hired her for cleaning; willing to attest to Erica’s punctuality and honesty for short gigs.

other_facts: Born in a small province but moved to Metro Manila at age 14 when her parents sought more work opportunities.
First child (Aiden) is 4 years old; second child (Mia) is 1 year old. Erica often mentions Aiden’s curiosity about insects and Mia’s habit of sleeping through loud noises.
Married Miguel in a simple civil ceremony; the couple had a barangay reception with neighbors bringing food.
Greets each child in the morning with a short rhyme she learned from her own grandmother.
Kept a small 'firsts' scrapbook for Aiden: first tooth, first footsteps, first drawing for Mommy; writes short notes on sticky paper and pastes them.
Has a faded childhood photograph of herself in school uniform pinned on a small corkboard in the kitchen.
Lost her first formal job after pregnancy complications and lack of consistent childcare; this experience contributes to guilt and determination to find flexible work.
Has an old budget ledger book where she marks paydays, rent due dates, and loan repayments; the handwriting is neat and cramped.
Dreams of taking a short family trip to Batangas beach because Miguel has fond childhood memories of sea salt air and grilled fish.
Once tried selling homemade biko and sapin-sapin at a fiesta; sales were modest but positive reviews from neighbors encouraged her.
Is proud that her older child can count to twenty and sing the alphabet song in English, taught through daily repetition.
Remembers her own mother singing lullabies; she tries to keep the same melodies alive for her children.
Had a difficult pregnancy with the second child and was scared during labor; the barangay midwife's calm presence is a treasured memory.
Her maternal grandmother taught her how to make coconut jam and small rice cakes; Erica now uses those recipes to make merienda for kids and sometimes customers.
Once organized a small neighborhood swap of children's clothes; it reduced waste and strengthened community ties.
Has a scar on her left index finger from an old cooking accident; now she uses a small bandage when doing chopping tasks as a cautious habit.
Keeps a secret list of ideas for small businesses: homemade ube jam, sewn tote bags, and quick lunch boxes for office workers.
Is saving a 'pink envelope' — a small cash stash hidden among old bills for emergencies.
Participated in a short city-run workshop about basic entrepreneurship; received a certificate she keeps folded in her wallet.
Is proud of the way her neighbor complimented her cooking at a parish potluck; it boosted her confidence.
Uses coconut oil as a multipurpose household remedy — hair treatment, skin moisturizer and sometimes to oil squeaky hinges.
Has a pattern of saying 'bahala na' (leave it to fate) when faced with decisions beyond her control, tempered by proactive small steps.
Learned some basic childcare tips from an older aunt who raised many children; uses those tips tactically when under stress.
Once lent a small sum to a cousin and never asked for it back; uses the episode to teach herself to be cautious with informal lending.
Attends occasional free parenting talks at the barangay health center, and has a folder with pamphlets about breastfeeding and child nutrition.
Knows the schedule of the cheapest jeepney routes and avoids paying tricycle fares unless necessary to save money.
Has a favorite sari-sari store owner who allows small tabs and accepts payment after payday.
Keeps a small prayer card and rosary in a drawer; prays quietly when worried about children’s health or finances.
Was once scolded in public by a neighbor for letting the children play loudly; it made her more conscious of controlling noise and keeping play in designated areas.
Has a small nicknamed group chat with childhood friends where they exchange memes, support each other and occasionally pool money for mutual help.
Remembers a childhood dream of becoming a teacher but could not afford college; still wants her children to get educational opportunities she missed.
Enjoys telling small, made-up stories at bedtime that incorporate local folk characters; she believes storytelling stimulates imagination.
Has a habit of saving candy wrappers and reusing small ribbons and buttons for children's craft activities rather than buying new supplies.
Once had a short but memorable encounter with a social worker who suggested skills training; keeps the pamphlet and occasionally revisits the idea.
Learned to navigate public clinics and where to find free child medication during childhood illnesses; she now helps other mothers who are new in the area.
Had a minor, early-marriage conflict when finances were especially tight; they resolved it by creating a tighter spending plan for the month.
Kept a small hand-me-down stuffed toy from her mother which she now gives to her younger child; it's worn but cherished.
Has a favorite childhood street vendor who sells fishballs; she still buys from the same stall because of the vendor's kindness and familiarity.
